With this increasing awareness will come\nincreasing scrutiny, as programs are asked to\nprove their effectiveness while vying for limited\nresources.  It is, therefore, essential that\nprograms identify their purpose, goals, and\nobjectives.  The purpose of a program provides\nthe framework that sets the direction of the\nprogram, while the goals and objectives provide\na plan as to how the purpose will be achieved.\n\nIn addition, the program purpose and goals are\nthe foundation upon which other program\nelements are defined, such as the target\npopulation and program services.  Measurable\nobjectives will provide programs with a\nmechanism for evaluating their results.  Target\npopulation, program services, and program\nevaluation will be discussed in greater detail in\nsubsequent chapters, but they are mentioned\nhere in order to draw attention to the\ninterdependency of the steps and decisions in the\nprogram development process.\n\nWhen developing a program\u2019s purpose, goals,\nand objectives, it may be helpful to understand\nthe rationale and philosophy behind teen court\nprograms.  This chapter begins with a discussion\nof some of the recurring themes among teen\ncourt programs and concludes with practical\ninformation on developing a purpose, goals, and\nobjectives for a teen court program.\nSpecifically, by the end of this chapter, readers\nwill be able to\n\ndiscuss the concept behind the balanced\napproach mission and restorative justice\nmodel and explain its relation to goals of teen\ncourt programs;\n\ndevelop a purpose statement for a teen court\nprogram; and\n\ndevelop short- and long-term goals and\nmeasurable objectives for a teen court\nprogram.\n\nTHE BALANCED APPROACH\nMISSION AND RESTORATIVE\nJUSTICE MODEL\n\nOne of the emerging trends in juvenile justice is\nbased on the concept known as the balanced\napproach mission and restorative justice model.\nIn an attempt to provide equal attention to\noffenders, victims and the community, the\nbalanced approach mission, according to\nBazemore and Umbreit (1994), focuses on\n\naccountability;\n\ncompetency development; and\n\ncommunity protection.\n\nThe philosophy of restorative justice is based on\nthe following values and assumptions\n(McLagan, 1992, as cited in Bazemore and\nUmbreit, 1994):\n\nOffenders, victims, and the community\nshould be included in the response to crime.\n\nGovernment and local communities should\nassume complementary roles in responding\nto crime.\n\nAccountability is based on offenders\nunderstanding the harm caused by their\nactions, accepting responsibility for the harm\ncaused, and making amends.\n\nIt is through values espoused within this type of\nframework that goals of the balanced approach\nmission take on a more significant meaning\n(Bazemore and Umbreit, 1994). What is\ninteresting to note is that these same goals (i.e.,\naccountability, competency development,\ncommunity protection) recur throughout the\nliterature and program materials from teen court\nprograms.  Although they tout goals similar to\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\n42 American Probation and Parole Association\n\nthose found in the balanced approach mission,\nthe majority of teen court programs, like many\nother juvenile justice agencies, have not\nimplemented the elements inherent in this\npromising approach to their full potential.\nPrograms that follow a balanced and restorative\njustice model provide a means for reconciling\nthe interests of and meeting the mutual needs of\nvictims, offenders, and the community\n(Bazemore and Umbreit, 1994).\n\nImplementing programs based on the balanced\nand restorative justice model can be an ominous\ntask and often requires agencies to adopt a new\nway of viewing the roles of offenders, victims,\nand the community in the justice process\n(Bazemore and Umbreit, 1994).  With\nconsideration and active participation from other\njuvenile justice agencies, victims, and the\ncommunity, teen court programs can offer\njurisdictions an avenue to bring the philosophy\nof the balanced approach mission in juvenile\njustice into actual practice.\n\nAccountability\nOften society has difficulty determining where\nto affix the culpability for juvenile crime.\nResponsibility has been placed on parents,\nschools, the community, or the court system.\nAlthough each contributes to the problems that\nlead to juvenile crime, the individual\nresponsibility of the youthful offender cannot be\nignored.   Families, schools, communities, and\nthe juvenile justice system all must play a role in\nensuring that youth accept responsibility and are\nheld accountable for their actions.\n\nUnder the balanced approach mission,\naccountability refers to the need for offenders to\nmake amends to victims for the losses caused by\ntheir delinquent actions.  This entails not only\nthe action of making amends through avenues\nsuch as community service or restitution, but\nalso entails creating an awareness in youthful\noffenders of the harmful consequences their\nactions have on others, most notably victims\n(Bazemore, 1993).  In cases coming before a\n\nteen court program in which there is no\nidentifiable victim, the message still should be\nsent to teen court defendants that their actions do\naffect others, including their families and the\ncommunity as a whole.\n\nWhat is missing in many teen court\nprograms, however, is the link for\noffenders between the act of making\namends and the awareness and\nunderstanding of why it is necessary to\nmake amends.\n\nMost teen court programs require youthful\noffenders to redress victims and the community\nfor the harm caused through the provision of\ncommunity service and, in some programs,\nthrough oral or written apologies to victims and\nmonetary restitution (American Probation and\nParole Association, 1994).  What is missing in\nmany teen court programs, however, is the link\nfor offenders between the act of making amends\nand the awareness and understanding of why it is\nnecessary to make amends.  In its Report and\nRecommendations to Victims of Juvenile Crime,\nthe American Correctional Association Victims\nCommittee (1994, p.6) states: \u201cIn far too many\ncases, juvenile offenders leave the scene of their\ncrimes without any inclination of the serious\neffects of their acts or the devastating impact\ntheir crimes have on their victims.\u201d  Therefore,\nif a teen court program is to operationalize the\ngoal of accountability to its fullest extent, it\nmust not only create opportunities for youth to\nrepay victims and the community, it also must\nbuild in an awareness component that educates\nyouth on the impact their actions have on others,\n(i.e., victims and community).\n\nIn doing this, efforts should be made to involve\nthe community and victims actively in the\nprocess (Bazemore and Umbreit, 1994).  The\ncommunity plays significant roles in holding\noffenders accountable by providing locations for\noffenders to complete community service hours\nand by providing offenders with paid work\nopportunities, increasing their ability to pay\nrestitution.  At a minimum, victims should\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\nAmerican Probation and Parole Association 43\n\nprovide impact information (written or oral) on\nhow the crime affected them.  This information\ncan be used during the sentencing phase to\nprovide jurors with information to assist them in\ndetermining an appropriate sentence and to\nbegin the process of personalizing the crime for\nthe offender.\n\nCompetency Development\nUnder the balanced approach mission, the\ncompetency development goal emphasizes the\nneed for offenders to leave the juvenile justice\nsystem with skills that will enable them to be\nproductive participants in society (Bazemore\nand Umbreit, 1994).  Additionally, Norem-\nHebeisen and Hedin (1981) stress that to\ndecrease delinquency, one goal of peer\nprograms should be to provide at-risk youth\nwith skills that aid them when they find\nthemselves in situations in which problem\nbehavior is encouraged and supported.  Teen\ncourt programs can be effective in this area by\nteaching youth (i.e., youthful offenders and\ncommunity youth) necessary life and coping\nskills and then offering a meaningful forum in\nwhich to use and refine those skills.\n\nThe goal is for young people to carry\nover and apply what they learn through\nteen court when confronted with other\ndifficult choices and situations in their\nlives.\n\nThroughout their participation in the program,\nteen court defendants and youth volunteers will\nbe confronted by persons with differing\nviewpoints and backgrounds, which often\nmirror experiences and situations encountered in\nother aspects of their lives.  At times, these\ndifferences may cause frustration; however, the\nway youth learn to react and respond to these\ndiffering viewpoints and personalities is all part\nof the learning process.  The goal is for young\npeople to carry over and apply what they learn\nthrough teen court when confronted with other\ndifficult choices and situations in their lives.\n\nMost teen court programs are designed to\nintervene early (usually after a first offense) in\nthe delinquent behavior of a juvenile.  Some\nways in which teen court programs offer skill-\nbuilding opportunities for youthful offenders is\nthrough requiring the performance of\ncommunity service and participation in\neducational workshops.  In addition to holding\nyouth accountable, basic habits that the\nperformance of community service can instill in\nyouth include (Maloney and Bazemore, 1994)\n\nreporting to work on time;\n\ncooperating with coworkers;\n\naccepting constructive criticism; and\n\nsuccessfully finishing a task.\n\nEducational workshops can be designed and\noffered to defendants to assist them in\ndeveloping needed skills in specific areas, such\nas managing conflict and problem solving.  As a\nmeans to further the development, enhancement,\nand application of life skills, most teen court\nprograms require or encourage offenders to\nparticipate as a volunteer in the program, usually\nin the role of a juror.  The table is turned, and the\ndelinquent youth is offered an opportunity to\nexperience the other side of the justice system\nby determining consequences for a peer.  Staff,\nwho observe a youth\u2019s interaction with other\njurors and teen court participants, can identify\nyouth who are lacking in certain skill areas and\nwho may need additional assistance or an\ninformal referral for other services.\n\nTeen court is not a mock trial; the cases that are\nheard are real.  As a prevention program, teen\ncourt programs offer youth in the community\nvaluable education and hands-on experience in\nthe legal and judicial system.   This places youth\nvolunteers in positions that require a tremendous\namount of responsibility.  They assume roles\nthat give them the power to make decisions that\ncan have a direct impact on the lives of the teen\ncourt defendants.  Through these roles, young\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\n44 American Probation and Parole Association\n\nThe Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency\nPrevention (1993) based a major component of\nits Comprehensive Strategy for Serious, Violent,\nand Chronic Juvenile Offenders on the premise\nthat to effectively handle delinquent behavior,\nthere must to be a range of graduated sanctions\nand a full continuum of treatment and\nrehabilitative services.  Aside from assisting\ncommunity youth to develop needed skills to\nresist the pressures to participate in illegal\nactivity, teen court programs promote public\nsafety by offering jurisdictions an alternative\nprogram to juvenile court for nonviolent,\nmisdemeanor cases.  The rationale for doing so\nis that the number of cases being heard in\njuvenile court will decrease, and more time will\nbe allotted for juvenile court to hear more\nserious cases.\n\nSAMPLE STATEMENTS OF\nPURPOSE, GOALS, AND\nOBJECTIVES\n\nAfter considering the philosophy and rationale\nbehind teen courts, program developers need to\ntranslate the philosophy into practice.  Each\n\npeople can play an active part in addressing the\nproblem of juvenile delinquency within their\ncommunity.\n\nCommunity Protection\nThe right of the public to a safe and secure\ncommunity is at the heart of all justice programs\nin both the adult and juvenile systems.  As a\nmeans to help ensure public safety, the balanced\napproach mission calls for a shared\nresponsibility between the juvenile justice\nsystem and the community for the control and\nreintegration of offenders (Bazemore and\nUmbreit, 1994).  By helping youth develop and\nenhance needed life and coping skills and\neducating them on the legal and judicial system,\nteen court programs can cause youth to adopt\nmore prosocial attitudes, which ultimately can\nhelp protect the community.\n\nThis concept is illustrated by the personal\nstatement in Figure 4-1.  It was written by a 15-\nyear-old girl who, before her involvement as a\nvolunteer in the Buncombe County Teen Court\nProgram in Asheville, North Carolina, had\ndeveloped a pattern of shoplifting.  She was\nnever caught.\n\nFigure 4-1: Personal Statement of a Youth Teen Court Volunteer\n\nA few years ago I started hanging out with some guys that always got into trouble with the police. I knew\nwhat they were doing was wrong, but I didn\u2019t know exactly what would happen if we were caught. It\ndidn\u2019t take long for me to get used to their ways and fit in well. When we would go into a store, I always\nknew my part, and no one else ever messed up either. We never got caught, and after a while we all got\nvery cocky about things.\n\nThere was one time when we went into a store five times in a row, and the last two times there was a\npolice officer in there. It didn\u2019t bother us; we just tried to get as much as we could and if we got caught,\nwell, really we thought that the police were too stupid to catch us. The way we thought was an ignorant\nway of thinking, because a week after that my friends were caught at another store, I, fortunately, was not\nwith them, but it got me to thinking. What if I had been with them? If I had been caught, what would have\nhappened? Even though it got me thinking, I didn\u2019t quit doing those types of things. I still wasn\u2019t sure\nwhat could happen if I was caught.\n\nOnce teen court started in Asheville, I got into it. I learned about what could have happened if I was\ncaught, and that was when I decided not to do anything illegal again. If it hadn\u2019t been for teen court, I\nwould never have learned about the consequences of doing wrong things and I would probably still be\ndoing them.\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\nAmerican Probation and Parole Association 45\n\njurisdiction should consider the philosophy\nwithin the context of its own community needs\nand resources.  Blindly implementing a program\nbased on its apparent success in other\njurisdictions is a simplistic solution that\nultimately may prove ineffective (Cochran,\n1989).\n\nBlindly implementing a program based\non its apparent success in other\njurisdictions is a simplistic solution\nthat ultimately may prove ineffective\n(Cochran, 1989).\n\nIt is advisable to include agency staff and\nstakeholders of the program (those who are\nsupportive of the program\u2019s efforts as well as\nthose who may be resistant) in the process of\ndeveloping the purpose, goals, and objectives.  If\na program is being developed within an existing\nagency, the program purpose must be in\naccordance with all other aspects of the\noverseeing agency\u2019s mission and must be\nacceptable to all involved with the program.\nAccording to Crowe and Schaefer (1992), some\nissues that may need to be evaluated by program\ndevelopers in this process include\n\nthe overall mission of the agency\nimplementing the program;\n\nlegal issues that may affect the program; and\n\nlimitations of community and program\nresources.\n\nThe following section outlines the process of\ndeveloping a program\u2019s purpose, goals, and\nobjectives.  When possible, examples used\nreflect concepts related to the earlier discussion\nof the balanced approach mission and restorative\njustice model.\n\nProgram Purpose\nA teen court program\u2019s viability depends on its\nability to address a pressing local problem.  It is\ncrucial that a teen court program focus on needs\nwithin its jurisdiction that can be addressed\n\nrealistically.  This will enable agencies to\ndevelop manageable, effective programs.  The\nfollowing two primary questions can help\nprogram developers limit the scope of a program\nto something that is realistic and achievable\n(Fulton, Stone, and Gendreau, 1994):\n\nWhat deficiencies are we trying to\novercome?\n\nWhich ones can we realistically overcome\ngiven the existing resources and level of\nsupport?\n\nA clearly articulated statement identifying the\nprimary purpose of the program will assist\nagencies in remaining focused on achievable and\ncongruent goals.  The purpose statement for any\nprogram, like an agency mission statement,\nshould clearly state the primary purpose of the\nprogram and the population for whom it is\ndesigned.  It also should include a very brief and\ngeneral description of the services it will provide\n(Fulton, Stone, and Gendreau, 1994).  A sample\nteen court purpose statement may be found in\nFigure 4-2.\n\nFigure 4-2: Sample Teen Court Program Purpose\nStatement\n\nThe Teen Court Program is a community-\nbased intervention/prevention program\ndesigned to provide an alternative response for\nthe juvenile justice system for first-time,\nnonviolent, misdemeanor juvenile offenders,\nin which community youth determine the\nappropriate sanctions for the offender. The\nprogram will hold youthful offenders\naccountable and provide educational services\nto offenders and youth volunteers in an effort\nto promote long-term behavioral change that\nleads to enhanced public safety.\n\nProgram Goals\nProgram goals are broad, general statements that\nserve to map out the future and provide a\nmeasure of success in achieving the program\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\n46 American Probation and Parole Association\n\npurpose.  They should clarify the intentions of\nthe program and direct program activities.  It is\nrecommended that agencies apply the following\nguidelines when developing goals for teen court\nprograms:\n\nFocus the goals according to the target\npopulation and program services provided.\n\nCarefully select the goals of a teen court\nprogram based on prioritized needs and\navailable resources.\n\nDifferentiate short- and long-term goals.\n\nA further discussion of these guidelines reveals\nhow their application can enhance the credibility\nof teen court programs.\n\nFocusing on Target Population and Services\nto Be Provided\nWhen developing goals, program developers\nshould keep in mind the target population the\nprogram is designed to serve.  If a program\ndecides to target first-time offenders, the goals\nand objectives of the program may differ from\nthose of programs targeting repeat offenders\nwho may need more intensive services.  Target\npopulation and program services are discussed\nin more detail in subsequent chapters.\n\nBasing Goals on Prioritized Needs and\nAvailable Resources\nStakeholder desires and jurisdictional needs\nshould not be ignored.  However, agencies must\nexamine and prioritize these needs.  This\nrequires an examination of the needs of youth in\nthe community and a determination of which\nneeds are not currently being met through other\nmeans and could be met through teen court.\nFunding and community resources need to be\nexamined to ascertain if the identified needs can\nbe met with existing resources or if the\ndevelopment of resources is feasible.  Realistic\ngoals that address a specific and important need\nthen can be established. (See Figure 4-3.)\n\nFigure 4-3: Sample Teen Court Program Goals -\nBased on a Prioritized Need\n\nPrioritized Need: A program to address the\nproblem of underage drinking and illegal drug\nuse in the community.\n\nLong-term goal: To decrease the number of\nyouth in the community\nengaging in alcohol and\nillegal drug use.\n\nShort-term goal: To intervene early, provide\neducation to, and promote\nawareness among youth of\nthe dangers of substance\nabuse.\n\nDifferentiating Between Short- and Long-\nTerm Goals\nProgram developers may find it helpful to\ndifferentiate between short- and long-term goals\nof the teen court program.  Some goals may\nhave a rehabilitative focus associated with long-\nterm behavior change. These may be easier to\nevaluate if refocused and broken down into\nshort-term goals that support the long-term goal.\nAlso, it may be easier to sustain internal and\nexternal program support if people can see goals\nbeing achieved in the short-term.  Figure 4-4\nprovides an example.\n\nFigure 4-4: Sample Teen Court Program Long- and\nShort-Term Goals\n\nLong-term goal: Improve the capacity of\nyouth to become\nresponsible and productive\ncitizens.\n\nShort-term goal: Provide youth with education\nand hands-on experience in\nthe judical systems.\n\nShort-term goal: Increase life and coping skills\nof youth in the community.\n\nLong-term goal: Protect the community.\n\nShort-term goal: Hold youthful offenders\naccountable.\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\nAmerican Probation and Parole Association 47\n\nProgram Objectives\nObjectives are crucial to effective program\nimplementation and evaluation.  Program\nobjectives specify how program goals will be\nachieved and should include a method for\nevaluating results.  While program goals should\nclearly state the intentions of a program,\nobjectives should describe the mechanisms and\nstrategies used to accomplish those intentions.\n\nSpecific and measurable objectives should be\nassigned to each major goal area.  Objectives\nshould be achieved within a limited time and be\nidentified with an actual result.  It is\nrecommended that teen court objectives be\nresult-oriented rather than activity-oriented\n(Crowe and Schaefer, 1992; Fulton, Stone, and\nGendreau, 1994).  Some sample goals and\nobjectives may be found in Figure 4-5.\n\nFigure 4-5: Sample Teen Court Program Goals and Objectives\n\nLong-term goal: Improve the capacity of youth to become responsible and productive citizens.\n\nShort-term goal: Provide youth with education and hands-on experience in the judicial system.\n\nobjective 1: 90% of youth attending the five-week teen court training seminar will pass a teen court bar\nexam.\n\nobjective 2: All youth volunteers will be scheduled to participate in a teen court trial/hearing within\nthree months of passing their bar examination.\n\nShort-term goal: Increase life and coping skills of youth in the community.\n\nobjective 1: 30% of the ongoing youth volunteer pool will consist of past teen court defendants by the\nend of fiscal year 1996.\n\nobjective 2: 85% of youth volunteers will complete a six-week life skills class during fiscal year 1996.\n\nLong-term goal: Protect the community.\n\nShort-term goal: Hold youthful offenders accountable.\n\nobjective 1: All referrals to the teen court program will be docketed and heard in teen court within five\nweeks of the referral.\n\nobjective 2: During fiscal year 1996, 80% of teen court defendants will successfully complete their\ncommunity service hours within 90 days of their sentence.\n\nobjective 3: 80% of all restitution payments scheduled to be made during fiscal year 1996 will be\ncollected.\n\nobjective 4: During fiscal year 1996, 60% of teen court defendants will complete a four-week victim\nawareness class.\n\nLong-term goal: Decrease the number of youth in the community engaging in alcohol and illegal drug\nuse.\n\nShort-term goal: Intervene early, provide education to, and promote awareness among youth of the\ndangers of substance abuse.\n\nobjective 1: During fiscal year 1996, 95% of all teen court defendants charged with an alcohol/drug\noffense will attend a Mothers Against Drunk Driving victim impact panel.\n\nobjective 2: 80% of all teen court defendants will successfully complete a four-week substance abuse\nawareness program.\n\nobjective 3: A pretest and three-month followup test (designed to assess change in knowledge and\nattitude about alcohol and drug use among adolescents) will be administered to all\nparticipants of the substance abuse awareness program. 80% of participants will show a\npositive change in knowledge and attitude relative to alcohol and drug use.\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\n48 American Probation and Parole Association\n\nCONCLUSION\n\nThe establishment of a program\u2019s purpose,\ngoals, and objectives is critical to effective\nprogram implementation and evaluation.\nWithout a carefully considered purpose and\ngoals, the program will lack a clear direction\nand eventually may find its existence called into\nquestion.\n\nThe sample purpose, goals, and objectives\nprovided in this chapter are based on the earlier\n\ndiscussion of the balanced approach mission.\nIndividual teen court programs should develop\nrealistic and achievable goals that reflect the\nprogram\u2019s philosophical basis, jurisdictional\ndifferences, and target population.  Establishing\nreasonable goals and objectives will require\nmore work during the planning and development\nstages to ascertain what improvement rates are\nachievable, given the program aims and\nresources.  However, this investment of time and\neffort should pay off in the long run with a more\neffective program.\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\nAmerican Probation and Parole Association 49\n\nCHECKLIST FOR PROGRAM PURPOSE, GOALS, AND OBJECTIVES\n\nHave teen court program organizers or staff \u2014\n\n\u2751 Developed an understanding of the balanced approach mission and the restorative justice\nmodel?\n\nHoward Zehr (1990, pp. 230-231) developed the following \u201cRestorative Justice Yardstick\u201d as a\nmeans for providing juvenile justice agencies with guidance in moving closer to values and\npolicies consistent with the restorative justice model. "text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Workplace-Based Organizational Interventions Promoting Mental Health and Happiness among Healthcare Workers: A Realist Review&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Mental illness, deemed globally to account for 32% of years lived with a disability, generates significant impacts on workplaces. In particular, healthcare workers experience high rates of mental ill health such as burnout, stress, and depression due to workplace conditions including excessive workloads, workplace violence and bullying, which also produces negative effects on patients as well as on the happiness and wellbeing of those who remain at work. This review was undertaken to synthesize the evidence on workplace-based interventions at the organizational level promoting mental health and wellbeing among healthcare workers, to identify what has been receiving attention in this area and why, especially considering how such positive effects are produced. A search of three premier health-related databases identified 1290 articles that discussed healthcare workers, workplace interventions, and mental health. Following further examination, 46 articles were ultimately selected as meeting the criteria specifying interventions at the organizational level and combined with similar studies included in a relevant Cochrane review. The 60 chosen articles were then analyzed following a realist framework analyzing context, mechanism, and outcome. Most of the studies included in the realist review were conducted in high-income countries, and the types of organizational-level interventions studied included skills and knowledge development, leadership development, communication and team building, stress management as well as workload and time management. Common themes from the realist review highlight the importance of employee engagement in the intervention development and implementation process. The literature review also supports the recognized need for more research on mental health and happiness in low- and middle-income countries, and for studies evaluating the longer-term effects of workplace mental health promotion.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;P. Our explanations fall into three categories: (1) work and economic conditions, (2) social-psychological resources, and (3) health lifestyle. We replicate analyses with two samples, cross-sectionally and over time, using two health measures (self-reported health and physical functioning). The first data set comes from a national probability sample of U.S. households in which respondents were interviewed by telephone in 1990 (2,031 respondents, ages 18 to 90). The second data set comes from a national probability sample of U.S. households in which respondents ages 20 to 64 were interviewed by telephone first in 1979 (3,025 respondents), and then again in 1980 (2,436 respondents). Results demonstrate a positive association between education and health and help explain why the association exists. (1) Compared to the poorly educated, well educated respondents are less likely to be unemployed, are more likely to work full-time, to have fulfilling, subjectively rewarding jobs, high incomes, and low economic hardship. Full-time work, fulfilling work, high income, and low economic hardship in turn significantly improve health in all analyses. (2) The well educated report a greater sense of control over their lives and their health, and they have higher levels of social support. The sense of control, and to a lesser extent support, are associated with good health. (3) The well educated are less likely to smoke, are more likely to exercise, to get health check-ups, and to drink moderately, all of which, except check-ups, are associated with good health. We conclude that high educational attainment improves health directly, and it improves health indirectly through work and economic conditions, social-psychological resources, and health lifestyle. he positive association between education and health is well established, but explanations for this association are not. Well educated people experience better health than the poorly educated, as indicated by high levels of self-reported health and physical functioning and low levels of morbidity, mortality, and disability. Psychosocial variables and social determinants both have an important role in determining a person&#x27;s health and well-being. The psychological, social, and cultural dimensions of these issues can have an impact on a person&#x27;s behavior and health. Stress, education, poverty, social exclusion, discrimination, and violence are a few examples of these psychosocial determinants. These elements can be protective or, on the other hand, raise the risk of physical and mental illness and lower people&#x27;s quality of life. Social determinants of health are a combination of social, economic, and physical factors. They play a role in determining the patterns of illness, disease, and health that are observed in a population. They establish the circumstances in which people are conceived, develop, live, work, and age. Health and medical care, economic security, social and communal context, local geography and built environment, and education are all examples of social determinants of health. The connection between individuals and their social and physical environments frequently worsens poor health outcomes. Low socioeconomic position, unemployment, strained family ties, and hazardous neighborhoods have been shown in studies to have a significant negative impact on mental health. The happiness of older residents is associated more with the provision of quality governmental services (i.e., performance variables). Health literacy refers to the ability to access, process, and use health information to make appropriate decisions to promote good overall health. Low levels of health literacy are associated with a host of negative outcomes such as less efficient use of healthcare services, higher healthcare costs, increased mortality, and poorer self-rated health. In those with medical conditions (e.g., diabetes), lower health literacy is linked with higher levels of depression. It is important to investigate whether mental health is linked to health literacy as understanding these links has the potential to identify those at risk for negative outcomes and thus implement protective strategies. Therefore, the current study sought to determine the extent to which various mental health constructs such as happiness, well-being, anxiety and depression are related to health literacy in a community-based sample of cognitively healthy individuals. We hypothesized that higher levels of health literacy would be associated with higher self-reported well-being, happiness, and lower anxiety and depression. Participants and Methods: Design - Cross-sectional, prospective study. Setting - Community-based. 93 individuals were included with mean age=59.02 years (SD=15.12) and mean education=15.70 (SD=2.39). 60% were women, the majority were White (55%) while 38% were Black and 7% belonged to other races; 90% were non-Hispanic. The effects of recreational travel on cognitive flexibility and originality&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract Recreational travel may increase creativity by relieving workers from stress, providing diversifying experiences and increasing positive emotions. Consequently, vacations may boost creativity, apparent in a greater variety (flexibility) and originality of ideas after work resumption. In our longitudinal field study, creativity (measured by Guilford&#x27;s Alternative Uses Task; independently scored by three raters) was assessed in 46 workers before and after vacation. Potential precursors for creativity changes (i.e. work load, vacation hassles, vacation destination and positive affect) were also explored. Cognitive flexibility increased whereas originality remained the same after vacation. None of the precursors explained variance in creativity changes. Although vacations seem to increase chances on creative insights by raising the amount of available cognitive elements (flexibility), they do not necessarily lead to higher levels of originality (uncommon, remote and clever ideas). Geurts&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2014,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Tourism Management&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/vacation-work-ticket-creativity-effects-travel-bloom/ce2345f50e685787a42a65d8549110fd/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/J.TOURMAN.2014.03.013&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;44&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;164-171&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:5},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The effects of urban inhabitants\u2019 nearby outdoor recreation on their well-being and their psychological resilience.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract With the shift to a service based society, providing opportunities for outdoor recreation that enables mental and physiological self-regulation has become an increasingly important landscape function. Recent research has provided considerable evidence that visits to near-natural everyday landscapes promote psychological and physical health. However, little is so far known about the effects of people\u2019s regular outdoor recreation in their local natural environment on their well-being and, in particular, on their psychological resilience. In our project we address this research gap by investigating nearby outdoor recreation behaviour in three urbanized regions in Switzerland, each of which has a different predominant culture and language (German, French and Italian speaking). A standardized questionnaire was sent to a random sample of residents ( N =1200) in each region. Stepwise regression supported the hypothesis that regular nearby outdoor recreation has a significant but rather marginal effect on respondents\u2019 reported well-being and their psychological resilience, even when systematically controlled. However, similar effect sizes, in particular in terms of psychological resilience, were found with other leisure activities. More generally, we found that well-being and psychological resilience were influenced by different factors, and that increasing psychological resilience mainly required a long duration of recreation or leisure activities. Management implications This paper provides robust evidence that urban inhabitants\u2019 regular outdoor recreation in the nearby natural environment has positive effects on their emotional well-being and their psychological resilience. The findings suggest that the quality of the nearby recreation area is at least an as important condition for these benefits as the easy access to these areas. Inhabitants\u2019 satisfaction with the recreation area, their activity level within the recreation areas as well as the time spent in the recreation areas appeared to be more relevant predictors for these benefits than the frequency of visits in these areas. Accordingly, managers should invest as much resources in increasing the quality of the recreation areas as in improving their accessibility.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. Main stress factors on the tours were identified as too tight time schedules, too little personal time and too much driving. \\nKeywords: Tourism, Tourist and travel activity, Psychological well-being, Happiness\\n South African Journal for Research in Sport, Physical Education and Recreation Vol.26(1) 2004: 97-106&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. Steyn&quot;,&quot;M. Saayman&quot;,&quot;A. Nienaber&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2004,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;South African Journal for Research in Sport Physical Education and Recreation&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/impact-tourist-travel-activities-facets-wellbeing-steyn/7a29288ac39d5b66a532d2ef87200c42/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.4314/SAJRS.V26I1.25880&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;26&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;97-106&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:7},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Modeling Recreation Choices over the Family Lifecycle&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Recreation decisions have traditionally been studied in tourism and leisure management. However, the topic has recently started to be studied on the transportation research field. This increasing interest in recreation travel reflects the fact that the share of recreation trips is rapidly increasing in many countries, and is expected to further increase due to changes in socio-demographics, lifestyles and other dynamic processes. Besides, these activities generate trips, and when summed up with the usual daily commuting trips contribute to emission levels and congestion and consequently, to the decrease of mobility and quality of life. In the Randstad area these mobility problems are even greater. Because of changes in the offerings of leisure and tourism products and services, the associated travel may contribute increasingly to emissions and a better understanding of this behavior from the perspective of sustainable development is therefore highly relevant. The individual\u2019s travel behavior may change over time, given different family lifecycle stages. For instance, the arrival of the first child may change drastically the recreation decisions of a young couple. Based on the exposed, the goal of this research was to better understand agenda formation and the dynamics of specific facets of recreation behavior as a function of lifecycle, controlling for others. The facets that make part of the recreation agenda formation (such as destination, transport mode, etc) are strongly dependent from each other. Thus, it is important to capture this notion of portfolio choice when studying recreation decisions. In the context of this research, recreation includes both vacation (tourism) and out-of-home leisure activities. Several analyses were performed, based on four different sources of data. The first dataset is a panel called CVO collected by NBTC-NIPO, where 838 respondents were followed from 2002 to 2009. It collects information about the annual holiday behavior of Dutch people. Several analyses were performed with the goal of exploring the determinants of vacation agenda formation of different lifecycle groups. A Bayesian belief network (BN) was applied in order to find relationships between lifecycle stages and other variables of the vacation portfolio. The resulting network showed the direct and indirect relations between socio-demographic variables and the variables that make part of a vacation portfolio. Some clear relationships, largely consistent with the existing literature, were found. Overall, the results indicated the interdependencies between choice facets underlying vacation portfolios and their relationships with certain socio-demographic variables. The focus was then shifted to the individual level, with the development of two models meant to better understand agenda formation and the dynamics of specific facets as a function of lifecycle stages, controlling for other variables. These models account for heterogeneity in individual preferences (mixed logit model). The first model explored transport mode choice, and in addition, complementarity and substitution patterns between the transport mode alternatives. Results demonstrated that the proposed model formulation is valuable to analyze tourist\u2019s choices over time as it allows parameters associated with each variable to vary randomly across individuals. Coefficients showed that Dutch tourists prefer to use the car for their vacation trips. The other modes act as complements to the car, whereas they substitute each other when car is not used for vacation trips. This may indicate that respondents tend to adapt to the available transport mode options. Car ownership seems to affect the decisions of the other tourist components (destination, travel party etc). The same holds for the contrary, for households without a car or when the car cannot be used because of imposed constraints, e.g., a destination too far away, the public transport options will then act as substitutes to each other. Based on the empirical results of the estimated coefficients for the interactions between transport mode choice and the socio-demographic variables (lifecycle and income), some conclusions can be drawn. First, the differences in behavior given individual\u2019s lifecycle stages can be explained in general by flexibility/constraints given age and/or household composition. Furthermore, the interaction between the transport mode choice and income resulted in coefficients that increase linearly as income level increases. The findings from this study also suggest that transport mode choice is strongly associated to the overall vacation profile decisions, as most of the interaction effects between the dependent and independent variables are significant. The other model developed based on the second dataset investigated choice of vacation length of stay. This dynamic mixed logit model accounted for both state dependency and heterogeneity in respondent\u2019s preferences. Length of stay options included short (1 to 3 nights), medium (4 to 9 nights), long (10 nights or more) vacations, and the decision not to go on vacation in a particular month in a specific year, used as the reference level in the model specification. The effects of seasonality, income, lifecycle stages characteristics and the influence of past choices in the choice of vacation length of stay were explored. Seasonality effects were accounted with the inclusion of month-specific variables. Results indicate that Dutch vacationers have preferences for taking their vacation during the main holidays periods and warm seasons. As for lifecycle stages, it seems that vacation choices are rather affected by the age of the children present in the household than by the age of the parents. In the case of income, results are in line with expectations and with the results shown previously on the transport mode choice model: utility increases with increasing income levels. The second dataset was collected through an Internet-based survey, using a software developed by our research group. The aim was to better understand the determinants of vacation choice of a sample of students. A literature review was developed, followed by a descriptive analysis of the student\u2019s past and intended vacation behavior. Further, a stated choice portfolio experiment specifically to analyze the factors influencing transport mode choice of students in the context of their vacation behavior. Results of the multinomial logit model indicate that costs predominantly influence their portfolio choices, especially because of the advent of the low-fare airlines. The attributes that are significant tend to amplify the specific role of transport modes in general and low-fare airlines in particular. The reference-dependent model for airlines preference confirm this finding as price sensitivity for low-fare airlines was higher than for the other modes. The third dataset was collected using a web-based survey. The 838 respondents who participated in the CVO data collection were invited to complete an online survey with a set of additional questions regarding their vacation plans. The aim was to explore if there are differences between choice facets in terms of when they are planned and to analyze the effect of lifecycle stages, income and travel experience in the level of vacation planning. Estimated coefficients show that the probability of a facet being planned increases as time to the vacation trip decreases, and that are differences in terms of when different vacation facets are planned. The fourth dataset is about leisure activities (CVTO), collected in 2008 by NBTC-NIPO. A BN model was developed in order to find direct and indirect associations between the variables. Then, a binary mixed logit model accounting for heterogeneity in individual preferences was estimated; complementarity and substitution patterns between leisure purpose alternatives were analyzed. Results demonstrated that the proposed model formulation is valuable to analyze individual\u2019s choices over time as it allows parameters associated with each variable to vary randomly across individuals. In terms of such substitution and complementary relationships between activity purposes it was found that outdoor activities decrease the propensity to perform sports or hobbies/courses activities. However, it increases the propensity to perform fun shopping and going out/culture. Based on the empirical results of the estimated coefficients for the interactions between leisure activity purpose and socio-demographics variables, some conclusions can be drawn. First, the differences in behavior given individual\u2019s lifecycle stages are in general explained by the flexibility/constraints spectrum typical of each group. Gender and social class exerts a small influence on activity purpose choice, although there are some differences between alternatives. The findings from this study also suggest that leisure activity purpose choice is strongly associated to the activity-related variables as most of the interaction effects between the dependent and independent variables are significant. The analysis of the importance of each attribute to the overall utility of an alternative indicates that especially lifecycle stages and travel party strongly influences activity purpose choice. The overall results in relation to the influence of lifecycle stages on vacation and leisure activities choice suggest that the differences in behavior given individual\u2019s lifecycle stages are in general explained by the flexibility or constraints typical of each group. Time and budget availability, and imposed constraints given age and/or household composition are the main factors explaining these differences. A better understanding of agenda formation of individuals as a function of their lifecycle stage characteristics is therefore highly relevant from the perspective of urban sustainable development.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Ab Anna Grigolon&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2009,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/modeling-recreation-choices-family-lifecycle-grigolon/2262706938c85f158880b009bbc68151/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.6100/IR741235&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:8},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Towards the recovery mechanisms of leisure travel experiences: does the length of vacation matter?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;ABSTRACT This research examines the recovery mechanisms of leisure travel experiences with a focus on the moderating role of vacation duration. Results from a sample of 509 US respondents shows that autonomy is a requisite in the link between tourism experiences and life satisfaction, while its effect on life satisfaction is mediated by passive and active tourism experiences. Another key finding is that shorter leisure trips tend to facilitate the passive route to life satisfaction, while longer trips can better facilitate the active route. To help us on this journey, Mark Anielski points\nto the promise of transformational work in raising our understanding about a\nnew perspective for how we conduct our present and future. \n\n\u2014 HON. ROY ROMANOW, P.C., O.C., Q.C., Former Premier of Saskatchewan,\nChair, Canadian Index of Wellbeing Network Board\n\nIf those who set the goals of society and measure success in reaching them \nbehaved rationally, they would long since have ceased to use per capita Gross\nDomestic Product as the major guide. Until now there has been no full-scale\nstudy demonstrating this and developing a more appropriate alternative.\nWith The Economics of Happiness, the last shred of justification for the exclusive\nfocus on market activity is gone. If this focus is continued, that can only mean\nthat those who profit from our wearing blinders control policy. \n\n\u2014 JOHN B. COBB, JR., theologian and co-author of For the Common Good\n\nWhat is the purpose of our economy and our work if not to support happy\nlives? In other words,\nmake room for ethics. That is the message throughout this book.\n\n\u2014 RT. HON. EDWARD R. In this power-\nful, insightful book, Mark Anielski exposes how this approach actually stunts\nour growth and prevents us from achieving a life that is rich in all senses of\nthe word. Breaking ranks with his fellow economists, Anielski shows how we\ncan make the economy serve the interests of society, not the other way around. \n\n\u2014 LINDA MCQUAIG, author and journalist\n\nMark Anielski\u2019s The Economics of Happiness provides an interesting and inform-\native look at money, economics, wealth and what it all means. The lessons in\nthis book provide a timely guide as our society begins the paradigm shift\naway from crass consumer capitalism toward more sustainable economies and\ncommunities where people and the planet matter. \n\n\u2014 DEAN KUBANi, Environmental Programs Manager \nfor the City of Santa Monica\n\nIn these times, even the best of us are falling short in courageously charting\nnew maps \u2014 and more importantly avoiding heading out without a map at\nall! Mark Anielski is a great pioneer of our time, and The Economics of Happi-\nness is \u201cthe emperor has no clothes\u201d rallying cry our world so desperately\nneeds. This book is a critical part of the architecture of a new system. It is a\nmust read for anyone serious about living differently with each other and the\nplanet. Quite simply \u2014 LOVE is the only true economics, and when we ex-\npress love it does not get used up, it multiplies.  \n\n\u2014 ANITA M. BURKE, Sustainability Elder and former Senior Advisor to the\nCommittee of Managing Directors at Shell International\n\nThe Economics of Happiness helps organizations evolve from satisfying \u201cShow\nme the money!\u201d demands from shareholders to satisfying \u201cShow me the gen-\nuine wealth!\u201d demands from stakeholders. Mark Anielski has provided a\ntimely guidebook for organizations undertaking that challenging journey.\nThis book is a must-read for enlightened business leaders. \n\n\u2014 Bob Willard, author of The Sustainability Advantage and \nThe Next Sustainability Wave\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page iii\n\n\n\nThe Economics of Happiness joins leading voices critical of the dominant econom-\nic paradigm, but it does much more than this. Being a critic is easy enough,\nand so is dreaming dreams. But designing the practical and modelled path to\nconnect the two in different and meaningful strategic alternatives, is the\nwork of exceptional people, and I rank Mark Anielski as one of these.\n\n\u2014 PROFESSOR MARILYN WARING, Institute of Public Policy, \nAuckland University of Technology\n\nMark Anielski is one of those rare Canadians, an economist/civil servant who\ncut loose from the system and became a true public servant. He did so by\nfollowing his values. In so doing he changed his own life, and we are all the\nbeneficiaries.
