Peter, an immigrant to\nCanada from Austria in the early 1920s, was a gardener all his life. He under-\nstood what made life worthwhile: the value of time spent with those he loved\nand in the many gardens he nurtured.\n\nTo my parents, Hans-Ulrich and Mary Ann Anielski, who taught me\nhow to dream and act on my dreams with conviction and leadership. They\ntaught me about how to live a life of faith, love, meaningful relationships and\nabout the virtue of meaningful, life-giving work as vocation. \n\nTo my life partner and wife, Jennifer Haslett, who has taught me the joys\nof love and reciprocal relationship; of reconciliation, laughter and most im-\nportantly of open and honest dialogue. And to our two daughters Ren\u00e9e and\nStephanie, who teach me every day about unconditional love and real hap-\npiness. Like my Opa and our elders, my children are teaching me how to\ncelebrate life in the moment of experience and how to breathe love in each\nprecious second of living. Children have a remarkable gift for asking tough\nquestions; this book is dedicated to answering some of those questions which\nstill linger into adulthood.\n\nLike the book of life, this book is the result of years of many wonderful\nconversations and enduring relationships with friends and colleagues around\nthe world. I would like to thank David Korten for encouraging me to write\nthis book and my students at Bainbridge Graduate Institute near Seattle,\nespecially Kate Kaemerle who took the \u0160rst steps with me on this journey by\ncompelling me to \u201cwrite it down, Mark!\u201d To Chris and Judith Plant and\nIngrid Witvoet of New Society Publishers for believing in my message. To\nBetsy Nuse, my wonderful editor whose loving edits have helped shape this\nbook into a crystal of wisdom. To Sue Custance and Diane McIntosh for the\nexquisite cover design that adorns this book, including the idea for a\n\nxiii\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/26/2007  12:21 PM  Page xiii\n\n\n\nFibonnaci sequence which is the golden ratio revealed in nature especially\n\u0161owers. To Jane Haslett, my mother-in-law whose unwavering dedication to\nthe initial edits of this book and her wonderful encouragement continually\nbuoyed my spirit. And to many other friends and colleagues who have in-\nspired and shared in my spiritual and earthly journey including Judi Hoyt,\nRobertFelty,AaronBraaten,AnitaBurke, JoeyHundert,MichaelHaynes,Bill\nHarder, Ernie Zelinski, Orest Andre, Dominic Misho, Boudewijn Wegerif\n(deceased), Jeff Wilson, Kelvin Hirsch, Randy Hirsch, Steve Janzen, Derek\nRasmussen, Pat Klak, Bernard Lietaer, Libba and Gifford Pinchot III, Pat\nCarmack, Mel Hurtig, Oscar Kjellberg, Karl-Heinrik Robert, Leslie Christ-\nian, Bob Willard, Bob Williams, Herman Daly, John Cobb Jr., Ken Chap-\nman, Marilyn Waring, Hazel Henderson, Janine Benyus, Linda McQuaig,\nHarold Wynne, Brian and Mary Nattrass, Michael Percy, Colin Soskolne, Bill\nRees, Dan Rubenstein, Sandra Zagon, Laszlo Pinter, John Rudolph, Edward\nSchreyer, Susan Sharpe, John McMurtry, Rob Smith, Sara Wilson, Rob Taylor,\nHeather Tischbein, Amy Taylor, Rob Macintosh, Peter Haslett, Joy Hecht,\nJohn Helliwell, Robert Putnam and Raf\u0160 Cavoukian. To all the others whom\nI treasure as friends \u2014 for real wealth is measured in terms of enduring rela-\ntionships.\n\nThis book is intended to inspire both current and future builders of the\nnew economy of well-being in the genuine pursuit of happiness and spiritual\nwell-being. I believe our hearts intuit better ways that are in genuine align-\nment with our core values to design, measure and manage our personal, com-\nmunity and world economies. We know that life is more than consumption\nand having more material possessions. We long to build living economies\nfounded on the premise of well-being that are just, sustainable and \u0161ourish-\ning; a society which is guided by the virtues of love, respect, shared responsi-\nbility, forgiveness, stewardship, cooperation, reciprocity, giving and receiving\nand restorative justice. This book is offered to those hearts and minds alive\nwith understanding the wisdom of the Dalai Lama, Pope John Paul II, Mother\nTheresa and St. Thomas Aquinas who teach us that love is the ultimate source\nof enduring power in the universe. \n\nMy \u0160nal thanks go to God and the Holy Spirit whose loving kindness\ntaught me to get out of the way of my own ego and sense of knowing and to\nrealize that all things come down to a singular breath: LOVE.\n\nxiv The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page xiv\n\n\n\nxv\n\nForeword\nby Herman Daly\n\nSUPPOSE THAT GOD sent an auditor to Earth to review the accounts of indi-\nviduals, \u0160rms, municipalities, and nations, with the purpose of assessing\n\ntheir stewardship of Creation and their success in converting resources into\ngood lives lived abundantly, righteously, and joyfully. What accounts or\nledgers would this auditor want to review, and by what criteria would he\njudge their adequacy? In reading this book I could not help thinking of Mark\nAnielski as \u201cGod\u2019s auditor.\u201d I do not want to attribute to Mark any divine au-\nthority or ability (he certainly does not claim such), nor am I sure that the\nAlmighty would not ask for some parts of the report to be redone. Of course\nan omniscient God has no need of an auditor\u2019s report, and the intended audi-\nence and bene\u0160ciary of the audit is us human beings.\n\nThe main criterion guiding the audit is \u201cgenuine well-being\u201d which is\nderived from \u201cgenuine wealth,\u201d which in turn consists of \u0160ve capital accounts\nthat assess both the quantity and quality of each type of capital. These \u0160ve\ncapitals are: (1) human capital \u2014 individual minds, bodies, spirits and their\ncapabilities; (2) social capital \u2014 quality and strength of our relations in com-\nmunity: trust, honesty, common values, including tolerance; (3) natural capi-\ntal \u2014stocks and funds of things in nature that yield \u0161ows of natural resources\nand life-supporting ecosystem services; (4) built capital \u2014machines, tools,\ndurable consumer goods; (5) \u0160nancial capital \u2014 money and other liquid as-\nsets, fungible and acceptable for payment of transactions and debts.\n\nOur current system of national accounts focuses on (5), pays some atten-\ntion to (4), and ignores (1), (2), and (3). The problem is that it is the \u0160rst three\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page xv\n\n\n\nthat are most responsible for genuine well-being. While there is some mar-\nginal substitution possible among these different forms of capital (often\noveremphasized by economists who advise not to worry about depleting, say,\nnatural capital as long as you accumulate an \u201cequal amount\u201d of built capital\nor human capital), it is important to recognize, as Anielski does, that the dif-\nferent forms of capital are mainly complementary. A shortage of any one lim-\nits the productivity of the others. In particular \u0160nancial capital quickly be-\ncomes worthless as natural capital is excessively depleted. And a lack of trust\n(social capital) limits the value of knowledge (human capital), etc. The fact\nthat \u0160nancial capital is the most measurable category has biased our attention\ntoo much in its direction. But just how measurable is money really? Do we\nmean M1, M2, or M3, and what kind of measuring rod is it that can be created\nout of nothing and then destroyed, and while it exists can become longer or\nshorter? We must not make a fetish out of measurability. What really counts\nis often not countable. Assets can be recognized and celebrated and main-\ntained and cared for even if we cannot add and subtract them.\n\nAnielski learns from many people: from Luca Pacioli the Italian inventor\nof double-entry bookkeeping, from Karl-Henrik Robert of the Natural Step,\nand Mathis Wackernagel of the Ecological Footprint analysis, and from many\nothers, including even me, which makes this old professor feel good. He looks\nat examples ranging from Ray Anderson\u2019s Interface Carpet Co. with its eco-\nlogical closed loop materials accounting, to China and the idea of xiaokang, or\nthe\u201cmoderatelywelloff society\u201dasanalternativetotheever-growing economy.\nHe studies the Italian province of Emilia Romagna, the Inuit, Bhutan, and\nthe city of Santa Monica. The style ranges from textbook to personal memoir,\nto philosophical re\u0161ection, but all aimed at elucidating and applying the con-\ncept of Genuine Wealth.\n\nSo, gentle reader, I will take up no more of your time with further sum-\nmary and endorsement. After all, you now have the book in your hands, so by\nall means read it carefully. You will be glad you did.\n\n\u2014 Herman E. Daly\n\nHerman E. Daly is currently Professor at the University of Maryland, School of Public Affairs,\nand has previously served as Senior Economist in the Environment Department of the World Bank.\nHe is the author of over a hundred articles in professional journals and anthologies, as well as\nnumerous books, including Beyond Growth and, with John B. Cobb, Jr., For the Common\nGood. He has received Sweden\u2019s Honorary Right Livelihood Award, and the Heineken Prize for\nEnvironmental Science awarded by the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences.\n\nxvi The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page xvi\n\n\n\nxvii\n\nIntroduction\n\nIBELIEVE WE ALL SHARE a common yearning for happiness and ultimately\nlove. Each of us has our own unique journey in discovering these ultimate\n\nends. But what are the determinants of happiness and our conditions of well-\nbeing \u2014 our genuine wealth? What, as Robert Kennedy challenged, makes\nlife worthwhile? How might we measure our happiness and incorporate these\nmeasures into conventional economic measures of progress like the GDP? \n\nPrompted by such nagging questions I began a journey into the origins\nof economic thought and economic systems. I realized that economics is more\nlike a religion than either art or science. The more I probed its tenets, the\nmore the scales of economic dogma fell from my own eyes and the eyes of\nthose with whom I shared my ideas. In a sense our hearts began to open to\ntruths that have long been sti\u0161ed.\n\nWhile some have de\u0160ned economics as the dismal science, I \u0160nd it akin\nto religion precisely because economic principles and tools form the guidance\nsystem of our modern states. Economists are the high priests of our capitalist\nsystems. I count myself among the economic priesthood \u2014 but I am a priest\nwho longs to understand the very premises and value-origins of our thought.\nAs a professor of business and economics, I have found a hunger among my\nstudents to understand more clearly the articles of faith behind business prac-\ntices. Many students question whether pro\u0160t and \u0160nancial wealth maximiza-\ntion should be the primary goals of business; they long for a more meaningful\nworld where corporations are governed by ethics and principles of social and\nenvironmental responsibility. I am buoyed by this new generation of business\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page xvii\n\n\n\nand economic graduates who understand at the heart level that the current\n\u201cnew world order\u201d can and must change.\n\nIn economics we have reduced humanity to a collection of individual, in-\ndependent, utility maximizing creatures. Success is de\u0160ned by the accumula-\ntion of material and \u0160nancial wealth over a lifetime. We are born into this free\nmarket ideology without questioning its morality or ethical foundations. So\nwatermarked is this spirit of economics and capitalism on our lives that even\nthough our hearts cry out for a more meaningful and genuine existence, we\nare sucked back into the squirrel cage of capitalism, running faster and faster\nto \u201ckeep up with the Jones,\u201d lamenting as we imagine a simpler, more mean-\ningful, more genuine life. \n\nI \u0160rmly believe we are at an important tipping point in human history. A\nshared consciousness is emerging which will be supported by enlightened,\nlife-af\u0160rming economics. This book presents my future vision: stewardship of\nwhat I call Genuine Wealth \u2014 those conditions of well-being that align with\nour heartfelt values about what makes life worth living. \n\nThe Economics of Happiness has four primary goals.First, I explore the nature\nand spirit of the current economic system. I want to better understand why\nmany in the sustainability movement can\u2019t seem to move towards a genuine,\nliving and sustainable economic system. I wonder how Adam Smith\u2019s seminal\neconomics text,TheWealth of Nations, failed toconsider theOldEnglishorigins\nof theword\u201cwealth,\u201dwhichliterallymeans\u201ctheconditionsofwell-being.\u201d The\nimportant work of Amitore Fanfani traced economic and capitalistic think-\ning back to the European Middle Ages where Fanfani located a pre-capitalist\nmodel that the sustainability movement may \u0160nd desirable.\n\nMy second goal is to introduce the concept of Genuine Wealth: a new\nand compelling model for managing our personal, household, business and\ncommunity well-being in accordance with the values that de\u0160ne our quality\nof life. Genuine Wealth is a practical system which measures and manages for\nsustainability the total capital assets of a community or organization. Syn-\nthesizing emerging concepts like natural capital and social capital, Genuine\nWealth creates a more comprehensive accounting system where human, so-\ncial, natural, built and \u0160nancial capital are all integrated into the balance sheet.\nThis vision of a living, sustainable economy is founded on the mutually rein-\nforcing and integrated principles of ef\u0160ciency, equity and reciprocity and was\ninspired by the cooperative economy of Emilia Romagna, a \u0161ourishing and\nvibrant region of Italy.\n\nxviii The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page xviii\n\n\n\nThirdly I provide examples of applications of the Genuine Wealth model\nat the personal/household, corporate/business, community, state/provincial\nand national scales. I present stories from Nunavut in Canada\u2019s Arctic, the City\nof Santa Monica, California and Leduc, Alberta and explore systems like the US\nGenuine Progress Indicators (GPI) and the Alberta GPI Sustainable Well-\nbeing Accounting System.\n\nFourthly I examine the nature of money and the current debt-based\nbanking system. Mountains of unsustainable debt and the practice of charg-\ning interest on loans actually lead to the destruction of living capital and\nfundamentally undermine sustainable economies of well-being and happi-\nness. I offer examples of alternatives to the current banking systems like the\nJAK Members Bank in Sweden, a cooperative member-owned bank that does\nnot charge interest on loans. I present a Genuine Wealth money and banking\nmodel that returns the power of money creation to the people in community.\nMoney could be created to serve the genuine needs of an economy of happi-\nness, and private banks, by providing wise \u0160nancial counsel to households\nand businesses, could contribute directly to the development of genuine\neconomies of well-being.\n\nWhile there is a growing library of books about sustainability, I offer\nhere a new paradigm which is also a pragmatic system for the management\nand stewardship of the common wealth of nations. While other books might\ndespair at the sad state of the world and our environment, The Economics of\nHappiness holds out hope that a genuine renaissance in economics, accounting\nand business practices is possible and that you and I can build communities of\ngenuine well-being and happiness, a vision that is shared by many. This book\nis optimistic and predicated on faith that people of all nations understand in-\ntuitively what needs to change in order for humanity to move towards a more\nsustainable future.\n\n\u2014 Mark Anielski\n\nEdmonton, Alberta, Canada\n\nIntroduction xix\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page xix\n\n\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page xx\n\n\n\n1\n\nChapter 1\n\nMy Journey to Genuine Wealth\n\nMany people have asked me \u201chow did you get to where you are?\u201d\nMy professional background includes economics, forestry, accounting\n\nand religious studies. After three university degrees and years working as a\nprofessional economist, I have developed an overview of the ways economic\nsystems operate throughout the world. In my inquiry into economic systems\nI continue to ask the simple question \u201cwhy?\u201d\n\n\u2022 Why do economists, \u0160nancial analysts, politicians and media \u0160xate on\ngrowth measures (such as the GDP or gross domestic product) as the key\nindicator of human progress? \n\n\u2022 Why do economy and stock market indices have to keep growing if a com-\nmunity has achieved levels of material self-suf\u0160ciency and quality of life?\n\n\u2022 What is money and where does it come from? \n\u2022 Why is money always scarce? \n\u2022 What\u2019s wrong with a steady-state, subsistence economy which has\n\nachieved suf\u0160ciency and homeostasis? \n\u2022 Why does free-market, capitalist economics look more like a cancer cell\n\nthan the self-renewing life cycle of an ancient forest? \n\u2022 What is driving our more-growth, more-consumption obsession? \n\u2022 Why aren\u2019t economists and our leaders asking hard questions: more\n\ngrowth of what? for whom? \n\nThese are just some of the questions I began to ask myself as an economist\nworking in the Canadian province of Alberta. As a senior government\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 1\n\n\n\neconomic policy analyst at Alberta Environment my primary task was to de-\nrive monetary value for Alberta\u2019s natural capital assets or natural resources;\nmany of them, like wilderness, had no price in a market. I was puzzled that\nwe had to reduce the value of everything to a monetary \u0160gure so it could\ncount. If something had no monetary value \u2014 like the joy of a wilderness ex-\nperience or the sight of a grizzly bear \u2014 did this mean that it was worthless?\nI began questioning the meaning of the word value. I was learning that there\nmight be market and non-market values. Economist and author Marilyn\nWaring offered my \u0160rst plain language lesson in the art of national income ac-\ncounting and the shortcomings of the gross domestic product (GDP) as a\nmeasure of progress.1 Marilyn noted that if you want fantastic GDP growth\nyou would deliberately crash an oil tanker like the Exxon Valdez into an\nAlaskan reef rather than deliver its cargo of oil safely to a Seattle port. Mari-\nlyn was the \u0160rst economist to point out to me the origins of the word value\n(from the Latin valere meaning \u201cshowing worth\u201d). Her warnings about the\nshortcoming of the GNP (the gross national product, the GDP\u2019s cousin) as a\nmeasure of progress had been voiced by Robert Kennedy in 1968 just a few\nweeks before his untimely assassination. Kennedy lamented that while the\nGNP might be great at adding up all the money we spend on goods and serv-\nices in an economy, it was a lousy measure of what mattered most to Ameri-\ncans: their quality of life. No other politician has given such a poignant cri-\ntique of the world\u2019s key measure of progress.2 For me, Kennedy\u2019s rebuke was\na clarion call to research and develop better systems of measuring human\nprogress and well-being that make common sense to average citizens and\nalign with their values.\n\nLearning about natural capital and sustainability\nWith these insights, I began to examine new models for measuring progress,\nsustainability and well-being. I began to explore new methods for accounting\nor measuring sustainability, \u0160rst focused on natural capital and then expand-\ning into other forms of capital accounting including human capital (like\ntime, knowledge and health) and social capital3 (like trust and the strength of\nrelationships). In 1991 I discovered the pioneering work of Robert Repetto at\nthe World Resources Institute in Washington. Repetto argued that account-\nants should treat nature\u2019s capital in the same way they treat manufactured or\nproduced capital like buildings, equipment and computers. Accounting\nshould acknowledge that nature\u2019s capital \u2014 like forests, oil and agricultural\n\n2 The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 2\n\n\n\nsoils \u2014 can either depreciate (that is, be depleted or degraded) or appreciate\n(that is, grow in volume or quality). Repetto\u2019s primary argument made good\nsense. I began to ask \u201cwhy don\u2019t we keep a balance sheet for nature\u2019s capital\nassets like forests, oil, gas, coal, wildlife, water and soils that are so vital to\nAlberta\u2019s and Canada\u2019s economy?\u201d I reasoned that economists ignored the\nvalue of nature\u2019s capital either because it was too hard to measure or count or\nbecause it was politically expedient.\n\nWith my curiosity piqued, I began informally examining Alberta\u2019s nat-\nural assets beginning with forests, oil/natural gas and carbon. Were Alberta\u2019s\nforests being managed sustainably? How many years of oil and natural gas\nsupply did Alberta have left? My preliminary results suggested that Alberta\u2019s\nforests might be approaching an unsustainability threshold: more trees were\nbeing harvested and destroyed by \u0160re and insects than the reported annual\ngrowth of the total forest. More disconcertingly, I lacked con\u0160dence in the an-\nnual growth rate of the forest. That was akin to lacking con\u0160dence in the rev-\nenue line on a conventional income statement or the interest rate on my bank\naccount! When I looked at oil and gas natural capital accounts, I was shocked\nto discover that the reserve life or years of future production of conventional\noil and natural gas left, at current production rates, was shrinking rapidly.\nBy my calculations Alberta would exhaust its precious oil and gas reserves\nwithin 12 years without new discoveries. Without information which natural\ncapital accounting provides to guide economic policy decisions, how could\nAlberta decision makers insure the long-term sustainability of Alberta\u2019s nat-\nural capital assets? How could there be so little interest shown in natural cap-\nital accounting practices by a government committed to accountability and\nperformance measurement? \n\nIn constructing these early natural capital accounts I learned an impor-\ntant lesson. While we had mountains of data and information, we seemed to\nlack the wisdom or capacity to understand what all the information was\ntelling us about sustainability. We had lost sight of the forest, so focused were\nwe on making money on the harvesting and export of trees. I realized that\nthere was an important role for accountants and economists to play in devel-\noping new capital accounting tools to assess the long-term sustainability of\nnature\u2019s capital assets as well as human and social capital. Economists could\nbegin developing revised national income accounts and adjusted GDP \u0160gures\nthat counted natural, human and social capital depreciation. I knew that such\naccounts could be constructed from the data we currently collected on the\n\nMy Journey to Genuine Wealth 3\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 3\n\n\n\nphysical state of our forests and other natural capital. Yet I knew that, like all\nmajor changes, a move to incorporate natural capital into the balance sheet of\nthe nation would be faced with resistance and reluctance to change. Fortu-\nnately almost 15 years later, the term natural capital has been popularized by\nothers (including by the Canada West Foundation in Calgary). Yet even today\nneither Canada\u2019s nor Alberta\u2019s income accounts or GDP \u0160gures count natural\ncapital assets that are critical to the well-being of Canadians. \n\nSince the early 1990s the idea of natural capitalism \u2014 that nature\u2019s as-\nsets or capital form one of the key foundations of an economy \u2014 has gained\npopularity in many books, countless articles and conferences. Natural Capi-\ntalism by Paul Hawken, Amory Lovins and Hunter Lovins contributed to this\ndebate. Its authors suggested that the world is on the verge of a new industri-\nal revolution founded on the principles of a system called natural capitalism.\nThey argued that traditional capitalism has always neglected to assign mone-\ntary value to its largest stock of capital \u2014 namely, the natural resources and\necosystem services that make possible all economic activity and all life. Nat-\nural capitalism, they stated, takes a proper and full accounting of these costs\nand redesigns industry on biological models that result in zero waste, shifts\nthe economy from the episodic acquisition of goods to the continual \u0161ow of\nvalue and service and prudently invests in sustaining and expanding stores of\nnatural capital. These words were music to my ears.4\n\nEncouraged by pioneering reports\nMoving to Alberta Treasury in 1995, I entered an exciting area: measuring\nthe overall performance of the government and the quality of life of Albertans.\nMeasuring Up5 was one of the \u0160rst triple-bottom-line performance reports in\nwhich a government described the conditions (using 24 core indicators) of\npeople, prosperity and preservation (the 3-Ps of progress). Measuring Up ri-\nvaled pioneer quality of life indicators in Oregon (Oregon Benchmarks),\nMinnesota (Minnesota Milestones) and Seattle (Sustainable Seattle). Alberta\nbecame one of Canada\u2019s (indeed North America\u2019s) models for government ac-\ncountability, business planning and performance outcome measurement by\nreporting to citizens on the outcomes of economic, health, social and environ-\nmental progress. The result expanded conventional economic reporting to in-\nclude such indicators as life expectancy, crime rates, educational attainment,\nthe sustainability of forests, the stock of oil and gas resources and the quality\nof air and water. Working with these new performance measurement and pol-\n\n4 The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 4\n\n\n\nicy outcome indicators provided a personal opportunity to see the world in all\nits complexity and begin to understand the true meaning of the word wealth.\n\nWe had begun to diagnose the conditions of well-being \u2014 by de\u0160nition\nthe real wealth of Alberta. I realized that if we could account for nature\u2019s cap-\nital through resource accounts, we could also expand our accounting into the\nunchartered waters of human and social capital accounting. I imagined a new\nway of taking inventory and a new expanded balance sheet for our nation,\nprovince, communities and businesses. If we could measure the conditions of\nwell-being of nature\u2019s capital assets, then we could measure the human and\nsocial conditions of our communities. \n\nIn 1997 a most remarkable study landed in my inbox: the US Genuine\nProgress Indicator (GPI). The GPI was developed by a group of researchers in\n1994, led by Cliff Cobb at the San Francisco-based economic policy think\ntank Rede\u0160ning Progress. The GPI is an alternative measure of economic\nprogress that starts with the GDP and makes adjustments for the value of\nunpaid work (e.g. volunteerism and housework) and for various social and\nenvironmental depreciation costs. While the GDP measures growth by the\namount of money exchanged for goods and services in the economy, the GPI\nattempts to measure well-being according to what most people might de\u0160ne\nas progress. For example, while the GDP currently adds things like the \u0160nan-\ncial costs of auto crashes or the social costs of problem gambling, the GPI\nwould deduct these expenditures as regrettable costs. The GPI represented a\nbaby step towards addressing both Robert Kennedy\u2019s and Marilyn Waring\u2019s\nchallenges that measures of progress should re\u0161ect genuine improvements in\nsocietal well-being. Economists could use GPI accounting to contrast GDP\ngrowth with such regrettable trends as the depletion of nonrenewable oil re-\nserves, the health costs associated with air pollution or the cost of failed per-\nsonal relationships. Most of us would consider such costs as regrettable and\nthus deductible as human, social or natural capital depreciation costs against\nnational income. The US GPI results for the period 1950 to 1995 showed a\nremarkable trend: while the GDP and GPI rose in tandem from 1950 to\n1973, the GPI reached its peak in 1973 and then declined steadily even as the\nGDP continued to rise. The economists\u2019 mantra that a rising tide of the GDP\nlifts all economic boats had been soundly repudiated. \n\nAfter reading the US GPI work I knew that my life as an economist\nwould never be the same and that a lifetime of new research and development\nopportunities lay ahead. The US GPI work inspired me to replicate this\n\nMy Journey to Genuine Wealth 5\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 5\n\n\n\nimportant well-being measurement in my home province of Alberta and\nthroughout Canada. I dreamed of creating a Rede\u0160ning Progress Canada and\ndedicating my professional life to developing more meaningful tools for\nmeasuring progress and well-being. Sometimes life sends wonderful surprises.\nIn the spring of 1998 Rede\u0160ning Progress asked to interview me for the posi-\ntion of Sustainability Measurement director in San Francisco to oversee future\nUS GPI work. It seemed the opportunity of a lifetime. My wife Jennifer and I\nwere \u0161own down to San Francisco during the Easter long weekend of 1998.\nWined and dined, I was smitten by the idea of working with such a talented\ngroup of creative researchers and living in San Francisco! During my series of\ninterviews with Rede\u0160ning Progress staff I presented my own vision of a\nmore expansive GPI/well-being measurement system that went beyond full-\ncost accounting of regrettable social and environmental costs included in the\nGDP. My vision was to create a system of well-being accounting that would\nmeasure what mattered most to people: their actual physical and qualitative\nconditions of well-being. I reasoned that behind the monetized GPI estimate\nof progress lay people\u2019s real experiences of living which could be measured\nand used to create both a new index of well-being, but more importantly a\nnew well-being accounting and reporting system.\n\nYet, as compelling as the idea of working with Rede\u0160ning Progress in\nSan Francisco was, my own quality of life assessment (comparing the realities\nof the high cost of living in San Francisco with life in Edmonton close to fam-\nily) revealed that Edmonton held a clear quality of life advantage. After many\nlong discussions with Jennifer and with my own full-cost accounting \u0160gures\nin hand, we concluded that a move to San Francisco would likely lead to a net\nloss in our overall family well-being. In the end, our relationship with our\nfamily and friends was more important than moving to a dream job and a\ndream city. Our decision was an important lesson in both my professional and\npersonal life and was a turning point. It brought my professional interest in\nwell-being measurement down to a practical and personal level. We had\nmade our decision about economic well-being based on a review of our values\nand what we felt mattered most to the well-being of our relationship: our\nchildren and our respective families. We had made a decision to stay home, in\nEdmonton \u2014 the community in which I had grown up and which Jennifer\nnow calls home. Our decision was not based on money, income or material\nquality of life but on intangible, qualitative attributes of life that cannot be\neasily quanti\u0160ed. Neither money, material gains nor career advancement\n\n6 The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 6\n\n\n\nmeant as much as being close to family, growing old with my grandparents\nand maintaining life-long friendships in Edmonton, North America\u2019s most\npopulous Northern city. I realize now in retrospect that we had made a choice\nbased on my \u0160rst personal Genuine Wealth assessment.\n\nAfter making this important decision, another door opened. Several\nmonths after the trip to San Francisco when I had returned to consulting work,\nI received a call from the woman who had accepted the position at Rede\u0160ning\nProgress. She said that the Ford Foundation (the key funder of the GPI work)\nwould like to see the GPI updated for 1999. \u201cUnfortunately,\u201d she said, \u201cI don\u2019t\nhave the skills to do the work. Would you be interested in performing the\nwork on contract and as a Senior Fellow?\u201d I was stunned. The opportunity of\na lifetime had returned. After contemplating the idea for a few days and dis-\ncussing the opportunity with Jennifer, I decided to leave my high-paid posi-\ntion as a senior policy analyst with Government Policy Consultants (GPC)\nInternational and conduct the US GPI work from my home in Edmonton.\nWorking closely with Cliff Cobb and co-author and journalist Jonathan Rowe,\nI completed the US GPI study update by January 1999. This work was a\ndream come true. It was one of the most important turning points in my career,\nopening up new windows of opportunity to work in this exciting and emerg-\ning \u0160eld of real economics.\n\nCompleting the US GPI work turned out to be one of the most challeng-\ning and arduous economic exercises I had ever undertaken. In Washington\nDC, I had the opportunity to meet some of world\u2019s most progressive econo-\nmists at the World Bank, Resources for the Future, World Resources Institute\nand the University of Maryland to discuss their views of the future of GPI-\nstyle accounting. Most were bullish that the GPI was an important measure-\nment effort that should be sustained, but that the model required more\nrigorous quantitative economic analysis to improve the full cost accounting\nestimates and care that the measure not become too value-biased. My most\nmemorable experience was sitting down with Dr. Herman Daly in his tiny\nUniversity of Maryland of\u0160ce. I consider Daly, one of the founding fathers of\nthe transdisciplinary \u0160eld of ecological economics, to be one of the greatest\nliving economists of our time and deserving of a Nobel Prize for economics. I\nasked Herman a question that would change the course of my economics\ncareer: \u201cIs it possible that our efforts at devising a money-denominated indica-\ntor of economic well-being (the GPI) might be futile since we are attempting\nto monetize quality-of-life issues which have value beyond monetary terms?\u201d\n\nMy Journey to Genuine Wealth 7\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 7\n\n\n\nDaly responded to my question with enthusiasm and encouraged me to pur-\nsue the answers with all of my life energy. His challenge has shaped my life in\nways I could not have imagined that afternoon sitting across from this hum-\nble, loving and courageous economist. To understand the importance of the\nnature of money and how it is created, Daly encouraged me to read Michael\nRowbotham\u2019s The Grip of Death (the title inspired by the French word mort-\ngage \u2014 meaning \u201ca pledge unto death\u201d) which was one of the most important\nbooks I read on my long journey to discover the nature of money.6 Daly ex-\nplained that over 90% of the world\u2019s money supply was actually created in the\nform of bank debts, not as paper currency created by governments. I then un-\nderstood that GPI-accounting paled in importance to more fundamental\nchanges required in the nature of money creation and banking. I later came to\nsee that the failure of the sustainability movement to understand and address\nthe nature of our debt-based money system would lead to a dead end street,\nsince genuine sustainability, based on principles of material suf\u0160ciency and\nsubsistence, is anathema to the high priests of our debt-money-economic-\ngrowth system.7\n\nIn January of 1999, my co-author Jonathan Rowe (an economic journal-\nist with Rede\u0160ning Progress) released the 1999 update to the US GPI result-\ning in almost no US media attention. The \u0160rst US GPI estimates by Cliff\nCobb, Jonathan Rowe and Ted Halstead in 1995 had won the attention of the\nAtlantic Monthly with a lead article and magazine cover proclaiming \u201cIf the\nGDP is Up, Why is America Down?\u201d8 Other media also inquired into the re-\nsults at that time. With the 1999 update, it seemed that Americans were\nmore intent on levitating stock market indices than on regrettable news of a\nsustained slide in the US GPI.\n\nBeginning the work in Canada\nIf updating the US GPI had been my economic Mt. Everest, my next goal was\ndeveloping a solid and permanent base camp to advance GPI accounting in\nCanada. I wanted to develop Rede\u0160ning Progress Canada and take the origi-\nnal US GPI work to a new level of sophistication and practical application.\nMy friend and former economics thesis advisor, Dr. Michael Percy now Dean\nof the Faculty of Business at the University of Alberta, gave me the chance to\ncreate and run a research think tank at the University of Alberta to explore al-\nternative accounting and measurement systems. What I had hoped to accom-\nplish in San Francisco I would try to do in Canada. I co-founded the Center for\n\n8 The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 8\n\n\n\nPerformance Measurement and Management to conduct applied research on\nalternative measures of economic well-being and performance. For two years I\nserved as the center\u2019s Executive Director and co-taught a course in business\nand the environment with Dr. Ray Rasmussen. During my time with the cen-\nter, my vision for expanding the original GPI accounting system took shape.\nThis was the genesis of the Genuine Wealth system. In the winter of 1999 I\ndeveloped a conceptual grand research agenda for creating a transdisciplinary\nnetwork (well-being.net) of University of Alberta\u2019s top researchers to work on\nthe development of a genuine well-being indicators accounting system. My\nmission was to design a sustainability accounting system for Alberta to assess\nthe long-term sustainability of Alberta\u2019s human, social, natural, produced\n(built) and \u0160nancial capital assets. Unfortunately, it soon became apparent\nfrom discussions with senior members of the University of Alberta that creat-\ning a place for such interdisciplinary research would take years of complex\nnegotiation.\n\nFortunately my vision of advancing GPI-sustainable well-being account-\ning caught the attention of Rob Macintosh, the co-founder of the Pembina\nInstitute for Appropriate Development, one of Canada\u2019s premier environmen-\ntal think tanks. In the fall of 1999, Rob encouraged me to join the Pembina\nteam on a part-time basis. I accepted the opportunity and began splitting my\ntime between the University of Alberta and the Pembina Institute. Rob asked\nme to co-author one of many green budget proposals for the National Round\nTable on the Environment and Economy (NRTEE) which would be present-\ned to then Canadian Finance Minister Paul Martin for his Budget 2000.\n\nI proposed that NRTEE create a research Center for Applied Sustainable\nEconomics. The proposed center, with a $10 million three-year budget, would\nhave two main goals: \n\n1. To apply improved or innovative methods for measuring the total wealth\nor well-being of Canadians that leads towards economic, ecological and\nsocial sustainability\n\n2. To revise existing \u0160scal policy instruments to help Canada move towards\na future where quality of life and competitive ef\u0160ciency are shared objec-\ntives in a world of ecological limits\n\nMy proposal also included revising national income accounts and the GDP to\nincorporate natural, human and social capital accounts to compliment exist-\ning economic/\u0160nancial accounts.\n\nMy Journey to Genuine Wealth 9\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:29 PM  Page 9\n\n\n\nThe \u0160nal version of the document proposed developing a set of environ-\nment and sustainable development indicators for Canada that would be re-\nported in parallel with other conventional economic indicators of progress.\nTo my surprise, the Chair of the NRTEE Dr. Stuart Smith fully embraced this\nproposal and brought it forward to Finance Minister Martin, who subse-\nquently announced a three-year, nine million dollar initiative in his spring\nBudget 2000. Martin\u2019s remarks as part of this budget presentation shocked\neven the most seasoned policy analysts when he stated:\n\nFinally, as we move to more fully integrate economic and environ-\nmental policy, we must come to grips with the fact that the current\nmeans of measuring progress are inadequate. Therefore, we are an-\nnouncing today that the National Round Table on the Environment\nand the Economy and Environment Canada, in collaboration with\nStatistics Canada, will be provided funding over the next three years\nto develop a set of indicators to measure environmental performance\nin conjunction with economic performance. In the years ahead, these\nenvironmental indicators could well have a greater impact on public policy\nthan any other single measure we might introduce [my emphasis].9\n\nI knew that a new era in economic reporting in Canada had begun. I spent the\nnext three years traveling to Ottawa as Sustainability Measurement Director\nof the Pembina Institute, developing Canada\u2019s \u0160rst set of environment and\nsustainable development indicators. Our work was completed and released in\nMay 2003. The \u0160nal results were somewhat disappointing: only \u0160ve natural\ncapital indicators (forest cover, freshwater quality, air quality, greenhouse gas\n(GHG) emissions, extent of wetlands) and one human capital indicator (edu-\ncational attainment) would augment familiar economic data, including the\ngross domestic product (GDP) and the consumer price index (CPI). However,\nthe most important outcome was the recommendation that Statistics Canada\nbegin to explore the options for expanding the System of National Accounts\n(from which the GDP is derived) to include more detailed information on\nnatural, human and social capital. If this recommendation was implemented,\nCanada would be the \u0160rst nation in the world to adopt a total capital account-\ning system that could measure the overall sustainability of the nation. Could\nmy recommendation to Paul Martin for a new balance sheet for the nation to\nmeasure the well-being or Genuine Wealth of Canada become a reality? I\n\n10 The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:30 PM  Page 10\n\n\n\nbegan to feel that the possibility existed, given the good fortune my journey\nwas enjoying on a provincial level.\n\nWhile still working part-time at the University of Alberta in January\n2000, I had proposed to Jason Brisbois, senior economist of the federal gov-\nernment department of Western Economic Diversi\u0160cation (WED), and Brant\nPopp, senior policy analyst at WED, a research project to develop the \u0160rst\nprovincial-scale prototype GPI sustainability accounting and measurement\nsystem for the province of Alberta. Both Jason and Brant were enthused by\nthe idea and suggested I submit a formal proposal. At the same time Rob\nMacintosh encouraged me to do this work through the Pembina Institute. I\ndecided to leave the University of Alberta School of Business and form my\nown Pembina Institute sustainability measurement research team. My re-\nsearch project proposal to WED was accepted in April of 2000, and a team of\n\u0160ve researchers at the Pembina Institute began work on the Genuine Progress\nIndicators Pilot Project \u2014 Alberta Case Study: Accounting for Sustainable Develop-\nment. Our goal was to develop a sustainable well-being accounting and report-\ning system with Alberta as the case study. I began to assemble my Alberta\nGPI research team: Amy Taylor (resource economist), Mary Grif\u0160ths (PhD\nmedical geography and scientist), Sara Wilson (ecological economist), Jeff\nWilson (ecological footprint analyst), with guidance from Barbara Campbell\n(accountant). We began by developing a blue-print for the Alberta GPI\naccounts identifying three key domains: economic/\u0160nancial, social/human\nhealth and environmental. Between April of 2000 and March of 2001 our\nPembina team developed 51 economic, social, health and environmental\nwell-being indicators (GPIs) accounting for Alberta\u2019s progress over four\ndecades from 1961 to 1999. We combed hundreds of statistical databases\n(mostly from Statistics Canada) to construct our well-being ledgers. We\nwanted to answer key questions: Has the overall quality of life of Albertan\u2019s\nimproved over forty years? Are we on a sustainable course for our children?\nWe built on the original US GPI full-cost accounting framework, estimating\nthe full costs of environmental, social and human capital values and deprecia-\ntion costs. We also expanded the US GPI model to what I envisioned as a new\nsustainable well-being accounting system with well-being ledgers that\nwould account for the quantitative (statistical data) and qualitative (opinion\ndata) conditions of well-being. Our 51 indicators, which included the GDP,\nwere based on the Alberta Government\u2019s 24 performance indicators for peo-\nple, prosperity and preservation in Measuring Up, plus other indicators that\n\nMy Journey to Genuine Wealth 11\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:30 PM  Page 11\n\n\n\nwe felt would resonate with quality of life issues important to Albertans.\nThese indicators included time spent with family and friends, volunteer time,\nleisure time, income inequality, personal debt levels, divorce rates, disease\nand suicide rates, problem gambling rates and the ecological footprint (a ro-\nbust measure of the sustainability of our individual lifestyles). Our overall\ngoal was to complete a comprehensive well-being checkup of Alberta, as a\ndoctor would complete an annual health checkup. \n\nAfter many long nights of research, number crunching and analysis we\nreleased the Alberta GPI report on Monday morning, April 23, 2001. Titled\nAlberta Sustainability Trends 2000: The Genuine Progress Indicators Report 1961\nto 1999, our report hit a home run in terms of media coverage. It made the\nfront pages of Canada\u2019s national newspaper, the Globe and Mail, on April 23,\n2001 with the title \u201cFat Cat Albertans Struggle with Happiness\u201d and the\nfront page of the Edmonton Journal with the title \u201cAlberta\u2019s Natural Capital\nSlipping.\u201d I was stunned by the media attention. The phone rang off the hook\nthat day. I was interviewed for CBC television\u2019s nightly newscast The National\nbroadcast on both French and English television channels. Radio interviews\nincluded Alberta-broadcast CHED 630 radio and CBC radio in Montreal and\nWhitehorse. After an exhausting media-frenzied day, I knew that we had\ntapped into a deep current of public consciousness. The average Albertan un-\nderstood that real progress should be measured by more than an increment in\nthe GDP or stock market indices. We had put a quality-of-life-reality-mirror\nup to the GDP using a Genuine Progress Index that revealed that while\nAlberta\u2019s GDP had risen an average 4.4 percent per year over the period 1960\nto 1999, the more comprehensive Genuine Progress Index had declined at an\naverage rate of 0.5 percent during the same period. Indeed, throughout the\n1980s and 1990s the GPI was virtually stagnant as the GDP continued its as-\ncent. The economic credo that a rising tide of the GDP lifts all boats had been\nrepudiated again.\n\nOur results were not unlike the US GPI study. Although Alberta\u2019s Gen-\nuine Progress Index had remained relatively steady throughout the 1980s\nand 1990s, the US GPI had been in steady decline since the mid 1970s. The\nGPI well-being diagnosis also revealed that the average real (de\u0161ated for in-\n\u0161ation) disposable incomes of average Albertans had stagnated since 1981\neven as the GDP continued to rise through to 1999. Most Albertans could re-\nlate to this reality. Other regrettable economic and social trends included ris-\ning rates of suicide, divorce, problem gambling and personal debt. Many of\n\n12 The Economics of Happiness\n\nEconoHappinessPress.qxp  4/19/2007  12:30 PM  Page 12\n\n\n\nthe environmental indicators also showed negative trends including declin-\ning oil and gas reserves, massive fragmentation of forest ecosystem and rising\nlevels of toxic waste production.\n\nOur report sustained media and public attention for several weeks. I was\ninvited to speak at numerous conferences about our \u0160ndings. We had provid-\ned the basis of an important dialogue in Alberta addressing economist Stanley\nK\u00fcznets\u2019 challenge: more growth of what and for whom? Interesting, but not\nsurprising, was the lack of any formal response from the Alberta Government\nand most notably from Alberta Premier Ralph Klein. Klein\u2019s response was\nsimply that we were entitled to our own view of progress \u2014 a compliment\ngiven his penchant for polemic outbursts. The relative silence from the\nAlberta Government suggested that our longitudinal well-being check-up of\nAlberta\u2019s economic, social and environmental progress was relatively fair and\naccurate. Our report had its critics, primarily economists who argued that the\ncreation of a composite well-being index was fraught with methodological\nproblems, including indicator selection biases and giving all indicators equal\nweight.
